original_text: Scientists have observed electrical activity similar to the brain activity of premature babies in lab-grown brains. The lab-grown brains are simplified versions of the organ that is grown in a lab for research purposes. They do not have brain regions to connect to, and they are also engineered to lack a protein that is essential for the normal function of neurons. By six months, the organoids were showing energetic brain activity. The activity was not like the organized, predictable brain activity of an adult, but it was similar to the chaotic bursts of brain activity seen in preterm infants. Some scientists are concerned with the results as it may mean that the lab-grown brains may develop consciousness if they were allowed to exist longer than the 10 months they are currently limited to.

original_text: Amazon is developing a technology that will allow customers to connect their credit card information to their hands, allowing them to purchase items with their palms. The company has been testing this technology, called Amazon One, in select Amazon Go stores in Seattle since 2020. With Amazon One, a customer would simply wave their hand over a scanner to pay for goods instead of having to use a credit card or cash. This technology uses a combination of computer vision algorithms and sensors to create a unique palm signature for each customer. This signature is securely stored and can be used to verify the customer's identity when making purchases. One of the benefits of Amazon One is that it could potentially reduce the need for physical contact when paying for goods, which could be particularly useful during the COVID-19 pandemic. However, some people have raised concerns about the use of biometric data, particularly if it is hacked or stolen. Amazon has stated that it takes privacy and security seriously and that the palm signature data is encrypted and kept secure. Customers can also delete their palm signature if they no longer want to use Amazon One. At this time, it remains to be seen if Amazon One will be rolled out to more stores or if it will become a widespread payment method. Nevertheless, it is an intriguing example of how technology is changing the way we pay for goods and services.

original_text: This article tells the story of how a startup was almost acquired by Facebook. It details how the company was founded, how it raised its initial investments, its growth, its dealings with Facebook, and ultimately how the acquisition fell through. The startup in question is a social networking platform called "Social Loop." Founded in 2015, the platform allowed users to create and join interest-based groups, connect with likeminded people, and share content. Initially, the founders funded the company themselves and built the platform from scratch. However, they soon realized that they needed outside investment to take the company to the next level. In 2016, the founders managed to secure a seed investment of 500,000 from a group of angel investors. This funding allowed them to hire a team of developers and marketers and begin scaling the platform. Over the next two years, Social Loop grew rapidly, with thousands of users joining every month. The company also raised a further 3 million in venture capital funding in 2018, which helped accelerate its growth. Around this time, Social Loop caught the attention of Facebook. The social media giant was interested in the platform's unique approach to social networking, and saw potential in integrating some of its features into Facebook's own products. After a few months of discussions, Facebook made an offer to acquire Social Loop for 50 million. Initially, the founders were thrilled at the prospect of joining forces with Facebook. They saw the acquisition as a validation of their hard work, and a chance to take the platform to new heights. However, as the negotiations went on, they began to have second thoughts. For one thing, they were concerned about the impact of the acquisition on Social Loop's existing user base. Many of these users had joined the platform precisely because it wasn't owned by Facebook, and they were wary of the social media giant's privacy practices. The founders worried that if Social Loop became part of Facebook, these users would abandon the platform in droves. Another issue was the founders' vision for the future of the platform. They had big plans for Social Loop, including expanding into new markets and developing new features. However, they were unsure whether these plans would be given the priority they deserved within Facebook's vast organization. Ultimately, the founders decided to turn down Facebook's offer. Although it was a difficult decision, they felt that it was the best one for the long-term health of the company. They continued to develop Social Loop, and eventually sold it to another buyer for 70 million, more than Facebook's offer. The story of Social Loop is a cautionary tale for any startup that is approached by a larger company for acquisition. While it can be tempting to take the money and run, it's important to carefully consider the long-term impact of such a deal on the company's vision, values, and user base.

original_text: Most object detectors enumerate a large list of potential object locations and then classify each item, which is a large waste of resources as well as an inefficient approach. Objects are often found in specific areas of an image and searching the entire image for potential object locations is unnecessary. To address this problem, some object detectors use region-based methods, where a few potential object locations, called regions of interest (RoIs), are proposed, and each of these RoIs is classified separately. This approach saves both time and resources, as it only requires a limited number of RoIs to be classified rather than searching the entire image. These object detectors often use convolutional neural networks (CNNs) to make their predictions, which is a type of deep learning algorithm that is particularly good at handling image data.

original_text: The basking shark is an endangered species that feeds on zooplankton, tiny creatures found near the surface of the ocean. It was once common off the coast of western Europe. A recent study has found that basking sharks like to travel to areas where there are high densities of zooplankton to feed. This causes hundreds of basking sharks to converge in inshore surface waters on the Scottish west coast, Ireland, and the Isle of Man. More than 80,000 basking sharks were slaughtered for their oily livers in the second half of the 20th century. The study reveals previously unknown behaviors about the sharks to conservationists, allowing them to more effectively protect the species.

Use Flexbox for simple layouts: Flexbox is a powerful CSS layout system that allows you to create flexible, responsive layouts with just a few lines of code. It's great for simple layouts where you need to align items vertically or horizontally. 2. Use Grid for complex layouts: Grid is another CSS layout system that's great for complex layouts with multiple rows and columns. It allows you to create responsive layouts that adapt to different screen sizes, and is perfect for creating magazine-style designs. 3. Avoid floats: Floats used to be the go-to method for creating layouts, but they can be unpredictable and hard to work with. Flexbox and Grid are much more powerful and reliable, and should be used instead. 4. Try out CSS Grid Garden: If you're new to Grid, try out the fun and educational game CSS Grid Garden. It'll teach you the basics of Grid in a playful and engaging way. 5. Use modals sparingly: Modals are great for displaying information or forms that the user needs to interact with, but they can be overused. Try to use them only when necessary, and consider alternatives like showing and hiding elements instead. By mastering CSS layouts, you'll be able to create beautiful, responsive designs that work across all devices. Good luck!

original_text: The same CSS code can sometimes output different and unexpected results. CSS is a complex system and subtle differences can change how properties behave. This article looks at layout algorithms and rendering engines in browsers, which can affect how CSS is interpreted and how content is displayed on a webpage. There are several layout algorithms used by different browsers, including block layout, inline layout, table layout, and flexbox layout. These algorithms affect how elements are positioned and sized on a webpage, and can lead to unexpected results if not accounted for in the CSS. Rendering engines also play a role in how CSS is interpreted. Different browsers use different rendering engines, which can affect how certain properties are applied or ignored. For example, some browsers may not recognize certain CSS syntax or may apply default styles to certain elements. To avoid unexpected results, it's important to test CSS code on multiple browsers and devices, and to use standards-compliant syntax. It's also helpful to understand the underlying layout algorithms and rendering engines used by different browsers, and how they might affect CSS behavior.

The method has endless potential applications, including noninvasive medical imaging, industrial inspection, and autonomous vehicle navigation. It works by combining multiple coherent light sources with different wavelengths, creating a synthetic wavelength that is longer than the individual wavelengths. By measuring the interference patterns of the synthetic wavelength, a holographic image can be reconstructed. This method is not limited by the line-of-sight, as the interference patterns can penetrate through obstacles such as walls and obstacles, making it a powerful tool for imaging in inaccessible areas. Additionally, the submillimeter precision enables the detection of small deformations and surface variations not visible to the naked eye, making it a valuable tool in fields like material science and engineering.

original_text: Physicists from the University of Iowa have discovered a new type of aurora in a nearly two-decade-old video. Diffuse auroral erasers are a part of the background-like glow of auroras , but they appear to wipe out small portions of the auroral displays for a brief period of time. This new type of aurora was first spotted by studying footage from a 2002 event, where a diffuse aurora was occurring alongside a more active auroral band. The researchers noticed that the diffuse aurora would momentarily dim certain parts of the active auroral band, as if erasing them. Further analysis revealed that this was due to a type of plasma wave that has never been seen before. This discovery highlights the complex and ever-evolving nature of auroras and the importance of continued research in understanding them.

original_text: Singapore currently produces about 10 percent of its food. Due to climate change and population growth, it aims to produce 30 percent of its food by 2030. In order to achieve this goal, the Singaporean government has implemented several initiatives to boost local food production. Some of these initiatives include: 1. Vertical farming: Singapore is promoting the use of vertical farming to maximise the use of limited land resources. Vertical farms take up less space while yielding more crops per unit of land compared to traditional farming methods. 2. Rooftop farming: Rooftop farming is a new trend that is gaining popularity in cities around the world, and Singapore is no exception. Rooftop farms are built on top of buildings, using previously unused space to grow crops. 3. Indoor farming: With the use of hydroponics and LED lighting, indoor farming can grow crops year-round, regardless of weather conditions, and with significantly less water than traditional farming methods. 4. Aquaponics: Aquaponics is a combination of aquaculture (the farming of fish) and hydroponics (growing plants in water). The waste produced by fish is used to fertilise plants, while the plants help to clean the water for the fish. This method requires less water than traditional farming methods. 5. Education and support: The government is also putting in efforts to educate and support individuals and organisations who want to participate in local food production. This includes providing grants, training and technical support. All of these initiatives show Singapore's commitment to increasing its food production capabilities and becoming more self-sufficient.
text: The government of Singapore is promoting a number of initiatives to boost local food production, including vertical farming, rooftop farming, indoor farming, and aquaponics.

The result is a generator that can produce highly realistic and varied images of faces. However, Darling has made great progress and can already run many popular macOS applications, such as Microsoft Office, Adobe Photoshop, and even some games. In addition to running macOS applications on Linux, Darling can also be helpful for software developers who want to test their macOS applications on Linux without having to switch back and forth between two different operating systems.

Currently, an array of these mushrooms is enough to power an LED light, but we are still a ways off from powering larger electronic devices.
